awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Control of Advanced Fuel-Flexible Multi-Cylinder Engines
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project will investigate the dynamics and control of advanced combustion strategies that have the potential to increase the efficiency of fuel-flexible diesel engines by up to 20 percent. The use of alternative fuels in modern vehicles typically results in higher production of some pollutants, as well as a drop in efficiency. However, the combination of alternative fuels along with more advanced combustion techniques has the potential to solve this problem, and provide efficient, clean power for transportation. While the benefits of this strategy have been demonstrated in highly monitored laboratory environments, significant improvements in the control of multi-cylinder engines are needed before these benefits can be realized in production vehicles. This project will create estimation and control methods for complex engine systems. The project will also provide  opportunities for underrepresented students to work in this critical area of transportation energy research.

The control of advanced combustion engines is particularly challenging due to the low availability of sensor measurements in the harsh engine environment, the highly nonlinear and internally coupled behavior of the system, and significant cycle-to-cycle and cylinder-to-cylinder variations. To meet these challenges, this research will study and model the dynamics of a multi-cylinder advanced engine system. With an improved understanding of the dynamics, the research team will then create nonlinear estimation techniques that capture key variables for which measurements are not available and which are primary drivers in combustion variations.  This project will culminate in the investigation of nonlinear model predictive control techniques that can provide optimal performance to this complex system with its constrained and coupled inputs. While reliable linear control techniques have existed for decades, control strategies for highly nonlinear applications such as advanced engines are not well established. Expansion of the current nonlinear control strategies to such systems will provide valuable insight not only for internal combustion engine applications but other complex system structures in areas such as robotics and hybrid vehicles.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: SENSORS AND SENSOR SYSTEMS FOR CIS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on the development of model-based control strategies for internal combustion engines that could improve their efficiency and fuel-flexibility. Over the course of the project, new models were investigated for compression ignition engines operating with a single fuel and in a dual fuel mode. Both physics-based and data-driven model techniques were explored to capture the complex air handling and combustion processes of modern internal combustion engines. In addition to modeling efforts, the project also explored the use of these models for engine control. Control of the underlying gas exchange and combustion was investigated using model predictive control as well as machine learning-based approaches. Comparisons of the benefits and shortcomings of physics-based, data-driven modeling and control frameworks were able to be explored and hybrid frameworks that leverage both physical understanding and data were able to be studied on this complex energy system.

These studies on modeling and control methodologies for internal combustion engines were complete for a range of fuels including natural gas, biodiesel and ethanol. As such, the strategies developed provide some of the tools necessary to ensure improved vehicle fuel flexibility. When using a range of fuels, it is critical to ensrue that the fuel burns at the proper time inside an engine to ensure that the efficiency is maximized. The predictive models for combustion created in this work allow combustion to be properly timed for a variety of fuels thereby providing a pathway to improving fuel efficiency. 

As part of this project, a senior level elective course focused on advanced automotive powertrains was also developed. This course provids students with an understanding of different powertrain architectures and helps them gain a comprehensive view of the current challenges in the automotive sector. Efforts were also made to improve engineering education during early childhood. STEM activities were integrated into first through third grade classrooms at a Chicago area school and surveys were done to try to better understand the role that such activities play in student's opinions on math and science at a young age. 


Last Modified: 03/22/2022
Modified by: Carrie Hall
